facts.text: Petitions Nos. 97 and 97A of 1956 filed by M/s Pannalal Binjrai and R.B. Jamuna Das Chowdhury under Article 32 challenging transfers under s.5(7A).

anchor.surface_text: petitions Nos. 97 97-A of 1956 The petitioners are M s. pannalal Binjrai, Oilmill owners, merchants and companymission agents, carrying on business at Sahibganj in the district of Santhal Pargans, having their branch at 94 Lower Chitpur Road, Culcutta, petitioner No. 1, and R. B. Jamuna Das Chowdhury, resident of the same place and erstwhile karta of the Hindu undivided family, which carried on business in the name and style of M S. Pannalal Binjr petetioner No. 2.

facts.text: Before September 28, 1954, petitioners in 97,97A assessed by Income-tax Officer, Special Circle, Patna.

anchor.surface_text: Before September 28, 1954, they, being assessed by the Income-tax officer, Special Circle, Patna.

facts.text: On September 28, 1954, Central Board of Revenue transferred cases of petitioners in 97,97A to ITO Central Circle XI, Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: On September 28, 1954, the Central Board of Revenue made an order -transferring their cases to the Income.tax Officer, Central Circle XI, Calcutta.

facts.text: On January 22, 1955, Central Board of Revenue transferred case of petitioner No. 2 in 97A to ITO Central Circle VI, Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: On January 22, 1955, the Central Board of Revenue transferred the cases of petitioner No. 2 to the Income-tax Officer Central Circle VI,Delhi,

facts.text: On July 12, 1955, Central Board of Revenue transferred case of petitioner No. 1 in 97 to ITO Central Circle VI, Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: and on July 12, 1955, it similarly transferred the cases of petitioner No. I to the same officer.

facts.text: Petitioner in Petition No.44/56 is Shri A.L. Sud, sole proprietor of M/s Amritlal Sud Construction, residing in Calcutta since 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner in Petition No.44/56 is Shrii A. L. sud, the sole proprietor of 14/B. Amritlal Sud  Construction  who orginally belonged to Hoshiarpur district in the State of Punjab but has since 1948 been residing and carrying on business in Calcutta.

facts.text: Prior to June 29, 1955, Shri A.L. Sud assessed by ITO Special Survey Circle VII, Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: Prior to June 29, 1959, he had been assessed to income-tax by the Income-tax Officer, Special Survey Circle VII, Calcutta.

facts.text: On June 29, 1955, Central Board of Revenue transferred case of Shri A.L. Sud to ITO Special Circle, Ambala.

anchor.surface_text: On June 29, 1955, the Central Board of Revenue transferred his case to the Income-tax Officer, Special Circle, Ambala,,

facts.text: Petitioners in 85/56 are M/s Bhagwan Das Sud Sons, merchants in Hoshiarpur.

anchor.surface_text: Petition No. 85/56 was filed by M s. Bhagwan Das Sud Sons, Merchants, Hoshiarpur, carrying on business in rosin and turpentine there.

facts.text: On October 20, 1953, Commissioner of Income-tax transferred case of M/s Bhagwan Das Sud Sons to ITO Special Circle, Ambala.

anchor.surface_text: Before October 20, 1953, they were being assessed by the Income-tax Officer,, Hoshiarpur, but on that date their case was transferred under s. 5  7A  of the Act by the Commissioner of Income-tax to the Income-tax Officer, Special Circle, Ambala.

facts.text: Amritsar group petitioners (86,87,88,111,112,158/56) prior assessed by ITO A Ward or F Ward, Amritsar.

anchor.surface_text: All these petitioners were, prior to the orders of transfer made by the Commissioner of Income-tax under s. 5 7A  of the Act, being assessed by the Income-tax Officer, A Ward, Amritsar,

facts.text: On or about June 29, 1953, CIT transferred Amritsar group cases to ITO Special Circle, Amritsar.

anchor.surface_text: but their cases were transferred on or about June 29, 1953, from the Income-tax Officer, A Ward, Amritsar, to the Income-tax Officer, Special Circle, Amritsar.

facts.text: Petitioner in 211-215/56 is Nandram Agarwalla, sole proprietor of Sriram Jhabarmull, business at Kalimpong with branch at Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: Though separately filed, the petitioner in each of them is the same individuals Nandram Agarwalla, who is the sole proprietor Of a business which he carries on under the name and style of I Sriram Jhabarmull.

facts.text: On July 27, 1946, Commissioner of Income-tax Central, Calcutta transferred cases of Sriram Jhabarmull to ITO Central Circle IV, Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: on July 27, 1946, orders were passed by the Commissioner of Income- tax Central, Calcutta, under s. 5  7A  transferring the cases of the petitioner to the Income-tax Officer, Central Circle IV, Calcutta.

facts.text: Petitioner in 225-229/56 is Kalloor Siddannal, commission agent in Raichur, Hyderabad.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner in each of them is the same individual, one Kalloor Siddannal who resides and carries on business in Raichur in the State of Hyderabad as companymission agent and distributor of agricultural products.

facts.text: On December 21, 1953, CIT Hyderabad transferred Kalloor Siddannal's case to ITO Special Circle, Hyderabad.

anchor.surface_text: On December 21, 1953, however, the Commissioner of Income- tax Hyderabad, issued a numberification under S. 5  7  ordering that the case of the petitioner should be transferred from the Additional income-tax Officer, Raichur, to the Income- tax Officer, Special Circle, Hyderabad.

facts.text: Shortly before May 19, 1955, CIT Hyderabad transferred Kalloor Siddannal's cases back to main ITO Raichur.

anchor.surface_text: It appears, however, that shortly before May 19, 1955, the Commissioner of Income-tax, Hyderabad, made another order under s. 5  7A  and s. 64  5  b  of the Act transferring all the cases of the petitioner to the main Income-tax Officer, Raichur.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on December 21, 1956 by Bhagwati J.

anchor.surface_text: 1956. December 21. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by BHAGWATI J.-These petitions under Art. 32 of the Constitution raise a companymon question of law whether s. 5  7A  of the Indian Income-tax Act,

facts.text: Section 5(7A) inserted by Indian Income-tax Amendment Act, 1940 (XL of 1940).

anchor.surface_text: This sub-section was inserted by s. 3 of the Indian Income- tax Amendment Act, 1940  XL of 1940  which was passed as a result of the decision of the Bombay High Court in Dayaldas Kushiram v. Commissioner of Income-tax,  Central  I.L.R. 194o Bom. 650,

facts.text: Explanation added to s.5(7A) by Indian Income-tax Amendment Act, 1956 (XXVI of 1956) following Bidi Supply Co. v. Union of India.

anchor.surface_text: By the Indian Income-tax Amendment Act, 1956  XXVI of 1956  an explanation was added to s. 5 7A  in the terms following as a result of the decision of this Court in Bidi Supply Co. v- The Union of India 1  Explanation

facts.text: Court holds s.5(7A) intra vires Constitution, not violating Art.14 or 19(1)(g).

anchor.surface_text: It follows, therefore, that s. 5  7A  of the Act is number violative of Art. 14 of the Constitution and also does number impose any unreasonable restriction on the fundamental right to carry on trade or business enshrined in Art. 19  1   g  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Transfers in Sriram Jhabarmull group (211-215) dated July 27, 1946 cannot be challenged as pre-Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear, therefore, that the petitioners are number entitled to companyplain against the said orders of transfer dated July 27, 1946.

facts.text: Amritsar and Raichur group petitioners acquiesced in transfers until after Bidi Supply decision on March 20, 1956.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Power under s.5(7A) is for administrative convenience in tax collection, guided by exigencies, not arbitrary; vested in high officials with presumption of proper exercise; no substantial discrimination as procedure post-transfer identical.

holdings.text: s. 5(7A) does not impose any unreasonable restriction on the fundamental right to carry on trade or business enshrined in Art. 19(1)(g)

anchor.surface_text: and also does number impose any unreasonable restriction on the fundamental right to carry on trade or business enshrined in Art. 19  1   g  of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.64 ensures local assessment as far as practicable, but primary object is proper tax assessment; hierarchy allows transfer for efficiency; precedents like Dayaldas Kushiram confirm.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affidavits explain administrative reasons (evasion, workload, interrelated cases, convenience); no contrary evidence; burden on petitioners not discharged; convenience afforded in hearings.

holdings.text: Prudent to follow principles of natural justice before transfer orders under s.5(7A) where circumstances permit

anchor.surface_text: it would be prudent if the principles of natural justice are, followed, where circumstances permit, before any order of transfer under s. 5(7A) of the Act is made

holdings.reasoning_summary: Obiter suggestion for notice, opportunity, brief reasons; contrasts with s.64(3); aids review but not mandatory as power administrative, not quasi-judicial.

anchor.surface_text: In the later case of Dayaldas Kushiram v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Central 1 , Beaumont, C.J., expressed himself as follows The Income-tax Act does not determine the place of assessment.

precedents.case_name: Dayaldas Kushiram v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Central

precedents.cited_holding: No right to assessment at particular place
